trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure is an open cloud platform that runs both Microsoft as well as non-Microsoft software which includes operating systems, application servers, messaging middleware as well as SQL and NoSQL databases from both commercial and open source models.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure is an open cloud platform that runs both Microsoft as well as non-Microsoft software which includes operating systems, application servers, messaging middleware as well as SQL and NoSQL databases from both commercial and open source models.

trans-unit.source: Building resilient services on public clouds including Azure requires careful planning and deliberate architecture for both applications servers as well storage layers.

trans-unit.source: Cassandra’s distributed storage architecture naturally helps in building highly available systems that are fault tolerant for cluster failures.
trans-unit.target: Cassandra’s distributed storage architecture naturally helps in building highly available systems that are fault tolerant for cluster failures.

trans-unit.source: Cassandra is a cloud scale NoSQL database maintained by Apache Software Foundation at cassandra.apache.org; Cassandra is written in Java and hence runs on both on Windows as well as Linux platforms.
trans-unit.target: Cassandra is a cloud scale NoSQL database maintained by Apache Software Foundation at cassandra.apache.org; Cassandra is written in Java and hence runs on both on Windows as well as Linux platforms.

trans-unit.source: The focus of this article is to show Cassandra deployment on Ubuntu as a single and multi-data center cluster leveraging Microsoft Azure Virtual Machines and Virtual Networks.
trans-unit.target: The focus of this article is to show Cassandra deployment on Ubuntu as a single and multi-data center cluster leveraging Microsoft Azure Virtual Machines and Virtual Networks.

trans-unit.source: The cluster deployment for production optimized workloads is out of scope of this article as it requires multi-disk node configuration, appropriate ring topology design and data modeling to support the needed replication, data consistency, throughput and high availability requirements.
trans-unit.target: The cluster deployment for production optimized workloads is out of scope of this article as it requires multi-disk node configuration, appropriate ring topology design and data modeling to support the needed replication, data consistency, throughput and high availability requirements.

trans-unit.source: This article takes a fundamental approach to show what is involved in building the Cassandra cluster compared Docker, Chef or Puppet which can make the infrastructure deployment a lot easier.

trans-unit.source: Cassandra can be deployed to a single Azure region or to multiple regions based on the distributed nature of the workload.
trans-unit.target: Cassandra can be deployed to a single Azure region or to multiple regions based on the distributed nature of the workload.

trans-unit.source: Multi-region deployment model can be leveraged to serve end users closer to a particular geography through the same Cassandra infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: Multi-region deployment model can be leveraged to serve end users closer to a particular geography through the same Cassandra infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Cassandra’s built-in node replication takes care of the synchronization of multi-master writes originating from multiple data centers and presents a consistent view of the data to applications.
trans-unit.target: Cassandra’s built-in node replication takes care of the synchronization of multi-master writes originating from multiple data centers and presents a consistent view of the data to applications.

trans-unit.source: Multi-region deployment can also help with the risk mitigation of the broader Azure service outages.

trans-unit.source: **High Availability:** The Cassandra nodes shown in the Figure 1 are deployed to two availability sets so that the nodes are spread between multiple fault domains for high availability.
trans-unit.target: **High Availability:** The Cassandra nodes shown in the Figure 1 are deployed to two availability sets so that the nodes are spread between multiple fault domains for high availability.

trans-unit.source: VMs annotated with each availability set is mapped to 2 fault domains.
trans-unit.target: VMs annotated with each availability set is mapped to 2 fault domains.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure uses the concept of fault domain to manage unplanned down time (e.g. hardware or software failures) while the concept of upgrade domain (e.g. host or guest OS patching/upgrades, application upgrades) is used for managing scheduled down time.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure uses the concept of fault domain to manage unplanned down time (e.g. hardware or software failures) while the concept of upgrade domain (e.g. host or guest OS patching/upgrades, application upgrades) is used for managing scheduled down time.

trans-unit.source: Please see [Disaster Recovery and High Availability for Azure Applications](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn251004.aspx) for the role of fault and upgrade domains in attaining high availability.
trans-unit.target: Please see [Disaster Recovery and High Availability for Azure Applications](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn251004.aspx) for the role of fault and upgrade domains in attaining high availability.

trans-unit.source: Note that at the time of this writing, Azure doesn’t allow the explicit mapping of a group of VMs to a specific fault domain; consequently, even with the deployment model shown in Figure 1, it is statistically probable that all the virtual machines may be mapped to two fault domains instead of four.

trans-unit.source: **Replication Factor and Consistency Level:** Cassandra’s build-in high-availability and data durability is characterized by the Replication Factor (RF - number of copies of each row stored on the cluster) and Consistency Level (number of replicas to be read/written before returning the result to the caller).
trans-unit.target: **Replication Factor and Consistency Level:** Cassandra’s build-in high-availability and data durability is characterized by the Replication Factor (RF - number of copies of each row stored on the cluster) and Consistency Level (number of replicas to be read/written before returning the result to the caller).

trans-unit.source: Replication factor is specified during the KEYSPACE (similar to a relational database) creation whereas the consistency level is specified while issuing the CRUD query.
trans-unit.target: Replication factor is specified during the KEYSPACE (similar to a relational database) creation whereas the consistency level is specified while issuing the CRUD query.

trans-unit.source: See Cassandra documentation at [Configuring for Consistency](http://www.datastax.com/documentation/cassandra/2.0/cassandra/dml/dml_config_consistency_c.html) for consistency details and the formula for quorum computation.
trans-unit.target: See Cassandra documentation at [Configuring for Consistency](http://www.datastax.com/documentation/cassandra/2.0/cassandra/dml/dml_config_consistency_c.html) for consistency details and the formula for quorum computation.

trans-unit.source: Cassandra supports two types of data integrity models – Consistency and Eventual Consistency; the Replication Factor and Consistency Level will together determine if the data will be consistent as soon as a write operation is complete or it will be eventually consistent.
trans-unit.target: Cassandra supports two types of data integrity models – Consistency and Eventual Consistency; the Replication Factor and Consistency Level will together determine if the data will be consistent as soon as a write operation is complete or it will be eventually consistent.

trans-unit.source: For example, specifying QUORUM as the Consistency Level will always ensures data Consistency while any consistency level, below the number of replicas to be written as needed to attain QUORUM (e.g. ONE) results in data being eventually consistent.
trans-unit.target: For example, specifying QUORUM as the Consistency Level will always ensures data Consistency while any consistency level, below the number of replicas to be written as needed to attain QUORUM (e.g. ONE) results in data being eventually consistent.

trans-unit.source: **Azure Considerations for Cassandra Cluster:** Microsoft Azure Virtual Machines capability uses Azure Blob storage for disk persistence; Azure Storage saves 3 replicas of each disk for high durability.
trans-unit.target: **Azure Considerations for Cassandra Cluster:** Microsoft Azure Virtual Machines capability uses Azure Blob storage for disk persistence; Azure Storage saves 3 replicas of each disk for high durability.

trans-unit.source: That means each row of data inserted into a Cassandra table is already stored in 3 replicas and hence data consistency is already taken care of even if the Replication Factor (RF) is 1.
trans-unit.target: That means each row of data inserted into a Cassandra table is already stored in 3 replicas and hence data consistency is already taken care of even if the Replication Factor (RF) is 1.

trans-unit.source: The main problem with Replication Factor being 1 is that the application will experience downtime even if a single Cassandra node fails.
trans-unit.target: The main problem with Replication Factor being 1 is that the application will experience downtime even if a single Cassandra node fails.

trans-unit.source: However, if a node is down for the problems (e.g. hardware, system software failures) recognized by Azure Fabric Controller, it will provision a new node in its place using the same storage drives.
trans-unit.target: However, if a node is down for the problems (e.g. hardware, system software failures) recognized by Azure Fabric Controller, it will provision a new node in its place using the same storage drives.

trans-unit.source: Provisioning a new node to replace the old one may take a few minutes.
trans-unit.target: Provisioning a new node to replace the old one may take a few minutes.

trans-unit.source: Similarly for planned maintenance activities like guest OS changes, Cassandra upgrades and application changes Azure Fabric Controller performs rolling upgrades of the nodes in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Similarly for planned maintenance activities like guest OS changes, Cassandra upgrades and application changes Azure Fabric Controller performs rolling upgrades of the nodes in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Rolling upgrades also may take down a few nodes at a time and hence the cluster may experience brief downtime for a few partitions.
trans-unit.target: Rolling upgrades also may take down a few nodes at a time and hence the cluster may experience brief downtime for a few partitions.

trans-unit.source: However, the data will not be lost due to the built-in Azure Storage redundancy.
trans-unit.target: However, the data will not be lost due to the built-in Azure Storage redundancy.

trans-unit.source: For systems deployed to Azure that doesn’t require high availability (e.g. around 99.9 which is equivalent to 8.76 hrs/year; see [High Availability](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_availability) for details) you may be able to run with RF=1 and Consistency Level=ONE.

trans-unit.source: Cassandra’s data center aware replication and consistency model described above helps with the multi-region deployment out of the box without the need for any external tooling.
trans-unit.target: Cassandra’s data center aware replication and consistency model described above helps with the multi-region deployment out of the box without the need for any external tooling.

trans-unit.source: Cassandra in a multi-region set up can help with the usage scenarios including the following:
trans-unit.target: Cassandra in a multi-region set up can help with the usage scenarios including the following:

trans-unit.source: **Proximity based deployment:** Multi-tenant applications, with clear mapping of tenant users -to-region, can be benefited by the multi-region cluster’s low latencies.
trans-unit.target: **Proximity based deployment:** Multi-tenant applications, with clear mapping of tenant users -to-region, can be benefited by the multi-region cluster’s low latencies.

trans-unit.source: For example a learning management systems for educational institutions can deploy a distributed cluster in East US and West US regions to serve the respective campuses for transactional as well as analytics.
trans-unit.target: For example a learning management systems for educational institutions can deploy a distributed cluster in East US and West US regions to serve the respective campuses for transactional as well as analytics.

trans-unit.source: The data can be locally consistent at the time reads and writes and can be eventually consistent across both the regions.
trans-unit.target: The data can be locally consistent at the time reads and writes and can be eventually consistent across both the regions.

trans-unit.source: **High Availability:** Redundancy is a key factor in attaining high availability of software and hardware; see Building Reliable Cloud Systems on Microsoft Azure for details.
trans-unit.target: **High Availability:** Redundancy is a key factor in attaining high availability of software and hardware; see Building Reliable Cloud Systems on Microsoft Azure for details.

trans-unit.target: On Microsoft Azure, the only reliable way of achieving true redundancy is by deploying a multi-region cluster.

trans-unit.source: Applications can be deployed in an active-active or active-passive mode and if one of the regions is down, Azure Traffic Manager can redirect traffic to the active region.
trans-unit.target: Applications can be deployed in an active-active or active-passive mode and if one of the regions is down, Azure Traffic Manager can redirect traffic to the active region.
